results.title: The Desert hopping mouse
results.creator_credit: David Corke and Educational Media International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Focuses on the spinifex hopping mouse of inland Australia to illustrate the many features it possesses which enable it to survive in what appears to be an extremely hostile environment. Also shows its daily activities, its methods of reproduction and the ways in which these may change with the seasons or from year to year. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Islands in the sky
results.creator_credit: Klaus Jaritz, Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the summer wildflowers in Kosciusko National Park. Discusses adaptation of the plants to the hostile environment and includes an alpine herb field, ferns and bogs.

results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Tom Morrison, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission
results.brief_description: A film which shows how man is making heavy demands on the earth’s remaining forests. A detailed study is made of the ecology of a eucalypt forest and the many plants and animals which make up the forest environment.

results.title: The Wetlands problem
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Australian Academy of Science, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: A case study of the Murray Darling River system which examines man’s relationship with his environment. Shows how the demands we have placed on this important river system for navigation, irrigation, water supply and recreation, have greatly altered it from its original condition. Poses the question, are we altering the ecology of the wetlands to a point where we may no longer derive the benefits we hope to enjoy from this river system?
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Australian Academy of Science, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: We discovered North Norway
results.brief_description: A train trip in the land of the midnight sun, through more than 500 tunnels. Per Host shows the grandeur of Northern Norway, which until recently very few Norwegians had ever seen. It is a geographical anomaly that here, north of the arctic circle, one can sun-bathe and swim in the fjords amid the towering peaks and plunging ravines.

results.title: Transport today
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Education Media Australia
results.brief_description: This film provides a brief survey of modern transport. The film has been produced without commentary, only natural effects, and has been designed as an introduction to the study of transport. The film does not deal with any one aspect in detail but shows a range of examples which makes a good starting point for inquiry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Education Media Australia

results.title: 'Where dead men lie': spotlight the director
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Chris McGill, Richard Mason and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the production of “Where dead men lie”, highlighting the role of the director, Keith Gow. This film shows his involvement in screen testing, location shooting, editing and mixing. Suitable for Years 7-12.

results.title: Olives don't float
results.creator_credit: Peter McKinley, Edwin Moses, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Peter Cummins plays an experienced seafarer who surveys the people and boats in the bay and points out the good and bad safety features of the various craft, their pilots and passengers. Production Manager: Penny Chapman. Cast includes: Frank Banset, Ray Sangston, Nino Ceron, Peter Eldridge, Jan Kuplis, Christine Ellison, Peter McKinley, Sven Kuplis, Julian Harvey, Peter Lewis.
